page.title: 16Chew Magna Reservoir
page.content: Chew Magna Reservoir, a compensatory reservoir to the rear of Broadcroft, was built in 1845 by the eminent Victorian engineer, James Simpson.It was then part of a scheme which took water from the Mendips near Chewton Mendip down to Bristol. The reservoir has an earth bank and the floor is of puddle-clay core which acts as a membrane against the passage of water. It is drained by a scour-pipe, the overflow being on the Broadcroft side. If needed,water is pumped at night into Chew Valley Lake when the cost of electricity is at its cheapest. At the moment Bristol Waterworks have drained out the water and are lining the scour-pipe with a plastic lining, renewing a valve, putting a concrete base in the stilling pond, making a new access road and making the crest of the dam wider.
